text: The 2003 Paris–Roubaix was the 101st running of the Paris–Roubaix single-day cycling race, often known as the Hell of the North. It was held on 13 April 2003 over a distance of . These are the results for the 2003 edition of the Paris–Roubaix cycling classic, in which Peter Van Petegem entered history by doing the double with his Tour of Flanders win, 26 years after Roger De Vlaeminck. This edition was run under clear skies and relatively good weather. ==Results== 13-04-2003: Compiègne–Roubaix, 259 km. {| class="wikitable" style="width:45em;margin-bottom:0;" |+ Results (1–10) |- ! !Cyclist !Team !Time |- !style="text-align:center"| 1 | | |align=right| 6h 11'35" |- !style="text-align:center"| 2 | | |align=right| s.t. |- !style="text- align:center"| 3 | | |align=right| s.t. |- !style="text-align:center"| 4 | | |align=right| + 15" |- !style="text-align:center"| 5 | | |align=right| + 36" |- !style="text-align:center"| 6 | | |align=right| + 36" |- !style="text- align:center"| 7 | | |align=right| + 36" |- !style="text-align:center"| 8 | | |align=right| + 36" |- !style="text-align:center"| 9 | | |align=right| + 36" |- !style="text-align:center"| 10 | | |align=right| + 1' 08" |} ==References== ==External links== *Race website 2003 Paris-Roubaix Category:2003 in French sport Category:2003 in road cycling Category:April 2003 sports events in Europe
